Award.AwardTitle: The evolution of development of flowering plant reproductive cycles
Award.AbstractNarration:
The great lability of their reproductive systems is central to the adaptability and rapid diversification of the flowering plants. With the origin of the group, ovules (future seeds) became enclosed within female tissues, necessitating a new site of pollen reception (the stigma) far removed from the site of fertilization (the egg). A critical innovation enabling this stigma-egg dissociation was the origin of a new pollen tube growth pattern in which sperm could be carried to the egg rapidly and through novel maternal tissues. The primary goal of this project is to understand the relationship between the evolution of pollen tube growth rates and reproductive cycles. The outcomes will bear on our understanding of ancient pollen-pistil interactions and floral biology, the focus of a great number of studies on more recently-evolved model and crop systems.

The project will involve detailed and comprehensive quantitative characterizations of early and late pollen tube development in four angiosperm taxa that span the deepest divergences among extant angiosperms using in vivo and in vitro field and lab experiments. The goal is to identify underlying developmental causes of variation in pollen tube growth rates. These fine-scale mechanistic studies will be accompanied by broad-scale comparative analyses probing the relationship between pollen development and important ecological traits, such as the speed of reproduction, floral sizes and longevity, and vegetative metabolic rates.

The PI has developed a synergistic teaching program in plant development and evolution that will provide graduate students with a focused intellectual environment. Training for a postdoctoral researcher and multiple undergraduate students is included. The project also features international collaborations, outreach, and teaching. The project bridges conceptual disciplines: the PI serves as a liaison between two NSF Research Coordination Networks, and is a founding board member of the Tennessee Plant Research Center. Outreach activities include public lectures and news media interviews.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Angiosperms, or flowering plants, appear relatively recently in the geological record but now constitute over 90% of living land plants. A remarkable number of the innovations said to underlie their rapid diversification function during their exceptionally short reproductive cycle, particularly the interval between pollination of the flower and fertilization of the egg cell (“the progamic phase”). The main goal of this award was to understand the developmental mechanisms that enabled such an accelerated fertilization process to evolve early in flowering plant history and to identify consequences of that shift. To that end, I undertook detailed microscopic studies of the fertilization process in what are considered to be ancient lineages of angiosperms, and then compared my findings with published results from many species of more recently evolved (“modern”) groups.

The duration of the progamic phase is determined by pollen germination and growth of the pollen tube, which carries sperm from the pollen grain to the egg. Pollen germination in modern angiosperms occurs on a timescale of minutes or hours, but is measured in days or even months in all other seed plants. I found that germination was rapid in many ancient angiosperms (eg. Fig. 1) and hence a shift to rapid germination probably occurred before the origin of angiosperms. There was considerable variation in the biology of pollen from ancient lineages (Figs. 2 and 3). An important result was the finding that the ancestor of monocots and eudicots probably had sexually immature pollen at the time of pollination (as do all other seed plants), whereas shifts to sexually mature pollen (sperm already formed) have occurred repeatedly within monocots and eudicots that have extremely rapid reproduction (Fig. 4).

Germination was found to constitute a minor portion of the progamic phase, therefore traits associated with pollen tube growth rates are primarily responsible for determining the duration of fertilization. Angiosperm pollen tube growth rates are 3-4 orders of magnitude faster than those of other seed plants, and indeed of any other type of tip-growing cell in plants. The main cause of this pattern was said to be the origin of insect pollination and floral traits that concentrate pollen on a common landing spot, the stigma. These traits increased the intensity of competition, generating the conditions for fast growth rates to evolve. I found that growth rate has evolved slowly in angiosperms, with extremely fast rates evolving multiple times, but only in very modern lineages. Pollen tube wall construction rate determines tip growth rate. Surprisingly, the genes for the major enzymes governing unique aspects of angiosperm tube walls (pectin methylesterase and callose synthase) were not novel, but had originated by duplication long before the origin of angiosperms. These genes were co-opted from their ancient functions into novel expression patterns that could produce a hardened, cheap, and quickly-produced pollen tube with a soft tip – a unique fast growth phenotype. I found both the gene transcripts and the fast growth phenotypes within ancient angiosperms such as Amborella, many water lilies, and star anises (Austrobaileya, Illicium). Establishing the homology of those genes with those of model angiosperms like Arabidopsis and tobacco provided a basis for the statement the exceptionally rapid growth rates of angiosperms were enabled by novel regulation of ancient seed plant genes.

Why there is so much variation in growth rates among angiosperms? Competition must be important, because for example, in comparisons between water lily species growth rates were slower in species with weaker competition (Fig. 5).
